instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Kelsa is a transgender high school student in her senior year.
2) She spends time with her best friends, Chris and Em, and makes YouTube videos about her life as a trans high schooler that she keeps a secret from her mother.
3) Her classmate Khal spends time giving thoughtful relationship advice to strangers on Reddit and hanging out with his best friend Otis.
4) He struggles with telling his parents that he wants to learn a trade rather than go to a four-year college.
5) Khal and Kelsa begin to develop a mutual attraction in their art class when they are partnered together to paint portraits.
6) Kelsa's friend Em admits that she has a crush on Khal and has Kelsa pass him a flirtatious note at lunch.
7) When Kelsa DMs Khal on Instagram to clarify the note was from Em, they begin talking frequently and become closer.
8) Khal wants to admit his feelings for Kelsa but worries about the social stigma of dating a trans girl, especially from Otis who frequently makes offhand homophobic and transphobic jokes.
9) On his brothers advice, Khal decides to bring flowers to Kelsa at school but panics when Otis asks who they are for and blurts out Em.
10) Chris overhears and tells Em and word quickly spreads.
11) After a panicked call to his brother, Khal decides to act on his feelings and gives the flowers to Kelsa at lunch.
12) Em leaves in embarrassment.
13) The next day he talks to Kelsa alone in an elevator and she confirms that she also has feelings for him.
14) They decide to go for it despite the risk of losing their friends and leave the elevator holding hands in front of all their classmates.
15) Khal stops spending time with Otis after he repeatedly asks Khal if he is gay, and Em breaks off her friendship with Kelsa entirely, trying unsuccessfully to convince Chris to do the same.
16) Khal and Kelsa go to a botanical garden on their first date and share their first kiss outside of her house after he walks her home.
17) Kelsa has a confrontation with Em in the locker room when she overhears Em spreading false rumors about Chris, which ends with Em falling and breaking her finger.
18) Soon after, Khal meets Kelsa's mother and makes out with Kelsa after she leaves them in the house alone, but they are interrupted by Chris.
19) Kelsa is nervous and unsure about the physical aspect of their relationship but Khal assures her that he is attracted to all of her and that he finds her beautiful.
20) They leave with Chris and go to a party.
21) At the party Em confronts Kelsa again and tells her that Khal is only dating her to seem woke.
22) She gets upset when he tries to comfort her and says that she can take care of herself and she is tired of everyone trying to protect her, and that she's tired of her transness being brought up in every aspect of her life.
23) Meanwhile, Otis and Em plan to fabricate a story that Kelsa attacked Em in the locker room in an attempt to break up Kelsa and Khal.
24) This results in Kelsa being banned from the women's locker rooms and bathrooms.
25) Khal shares a link to one of Kelsa's YouTube videos on Reddit and it goes viral, resulting in her mom finding the channel and forcing her to take it down out of concerns for her safety.
26) Chris rallies the students to protest Kelsa's ban from the women's room by refusing to use the restroom for their assigned gender and chanting in the cafeteria.
27) Kelsa is embarrassed and angered by this and angrily confronts Khal for sharing her video and making it go viral.
28) Otis blocks him when he attempts to go after her, and he eventually breaks down and punches Otis after he repeatedly misgenders and insults Kelsa.
29) When he returns home from school his parents confront him about his internet history that includes several trans topics, forcing him to admit he is dating a trans woman and leading to a tearful conversation with his mother about the stigma that has come with dating Kelsa.
30) During a meeting with the principal including Em, Kelsa and their mothers, Em admits that she made up the assault and apologizes after her mother expresses transphobic opinions, saying that she doesn't wish to become that kind of person.
31) Kelsa and her mother have a heartfelt conversation and reconcile, although Kelsa is still not allowed to put her YouTube channel back up until college.
32) Kelsa and Khal meet at the botanical gardens again and reconcile, bringing each other flowers and admitting that they need to be more open with each other and be willing to accept help when they need it.
33) They spend the remainder of the school year and the summer spending as much time together as possible.
34) As the summer nears an end, they agree to part amicably because Kelsa will be moving away for college while Khal stays home and pursues an education at a technical school.
35) After parting they reflect on how much they care for each other and how important they've been to each other, even if they were only meant to be together for a short time.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Kelsa, a transgender high school student.

Five major events in the story are:

1. Kelsa begins to develop a mutual attraction with Khal in their art class (event 5).
2. Kelsa and Khal decide to date despite the risk of losing their friends (event 14).
3. Em spreads false rumors about Kelsa, and Kelsa is banned from the women's locker rooms and bathrooms (event 24).
4. Em admits to making up the assault, and Kelsa's ban is lifted (event 30).
5. Kelsa and Khal decide to part amicably as Kelsa prepares to leave for college (event 34).

### 2. Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes at Each Event

1. At the first event, Kelsa begins to develop feelings for Khal, which improves her state as she feels a sense of excitement and possibility. Her state starts relatively neutral (5) and rises to (7) as she feels a connection with Khal.

State: 5 → 7

2. At the second event, Kelsa and Khal decide to date, and Kelsa feels happy and accepted. Her state rises further (7 → 9) as she feels confident in her relationship.

State: 7 → 9

3. At the third event, Em's false rumors lead to Kelsa being banned from the women's locker rooms and bathrooms, causing Kelsa significant distress and anxiety. Her state falls drastically (9 → 2) as she feels isolated and targeted.

State: 9 → 2

4. At the fourth event, Em admits to making up the assault, and Kelsa's ban is lifted, which brings relief and vindication to Kelsa. Her state rises (2 → 6) as she feels a sense of justice and acceptance.

State: 2 → 6

5. At the fifth event, Kelsa and Khal decide to part amicably, which brings a mix of sadness and acceptance to Kelsa. Her state remains relatively stable (6 → 5) as she acknowledges the end of the relationship but feels grateful for the experience.

State: 6 → 5

### 3. Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, the story arc type can be classified as Oedipus. The Oedipus arc is characterized by a high starting point, followed by a fall, recovery, and then another significant downfall. In Kelsa's story, she starts relatively high (5), rises to a peak (9), falls drastically (2), recovers (6), and then faces a bittersweet ending (5).

The story arc is not a perfect fit for the Oedipus type, as Kelsa's final state is not as low as the traditional Oedipus arc would suggest. However, the overall pattern of rise, fall, recovery, and decline matches the Oedipus arc more closely than any other type.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Oedipus

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Nestled comfortably amidst the lush, rolling landscapes of Ohio, the quaint town of Middleton was a sight to behold.
2) Within this calm, Officer Jack Reynolds, an adept law enforcer with years of experience, stood vigilant, his steel-gray eyes scanning the picturesque surroundings.
3) Among the blush of normalcy, a jade-colored Dodge Grand Caravan stood out starkly, bereft of the mandated registration stickers.
4) Jack's instinctual alarm flared, prompting him to investigate what appeared to be a routine traffic violation but promising potential hidden layers of intrigue.
5) The man at the wheel introduced himself as Stanley, his fingers jittering slightly as he presented a driver's license that looked suspiciously outdated for the current times.
6) The discrepancy did not filter past Jack, fuelling his suspicions further.
7) Only a few days following this incident, the tranquil peace of Middleton began showing cracks.
8) Residents exhibited signs of fear, unfamiliar symbols cropped up on building walls, all hinting at a connection to Stanley's recent arrival - a puzzle demanding Jack's expertise in putting together.
9) Bringing his concerns to his superiors at the police headquarters resulted in dismissive laughter and gentle ribbing towards his supposed active imagination.
10) Despite their lack of support, Jack couldn't simply brush off the brewing danger his instinct was warning him about.
11) Choosing to act on his alert intuition rather than give ear to skeptical colleagues, Jack delved deeper into Stanley's background.
12) To his horror, he uncovered a significant fact.
13) Stanley was an ex-convict with a history intertwined with occult practices - facts that startled Jack and set off alarm bells in his mind.
14) Immersed in his off-duty detective work, Jack did not realize that Stanley was watching him.
15) That oversight led to a dangerous confrontation in a gloom-ridden alleyway, landing Jack with a few nasty bruises and a larger, more potent determination.
16) Despite his physical injuries, Jack's determination only strengthened.
17) He was certain the disaster threatening Middleton had roots in Stanley's arrival, and he was hell-bent on averting it.
18) Decidedly alone in his defense of Middleton, Jack took on the role of a secret guardian, tracking Stanley's movements under the cover of the night, determined to catch him in the act.
19) This dedication eventually led him to a shocking discovery - a concealed underground bunker filled with multiple surveillance monitors, grotesque dolls, and cryptic symbols suggested of dark, mystic practices.
20) The grisly sight confronted Jack's senses, making him recoil in sheer dread.
21) But it also proved his suspicions, confirming Stanley's link to the town's disturbing happenings and the abductions.
22) Armed with this new evidence, he forced a meeting with the Middleton Police Chief, laying out all he had uncovered.
23) His persistence finally paid off as the skepticism was replaced with alarm, setting off a flurry of action within the department.
24) Stanley, however, had been alerted anonymously of his impending exposure, which initiated a deadly race against time to complete his horrifying plan.
25) The tranquility of Middleton was shattered, replaced with a desperate and chaotic manhunt.
26) Jack, unwilling to comply with the police's standard protocol, determinedly chose to face Stanley mano a mano.
27) His seasoned instincts pointed towards an isolated, abandoned lumber mill—the perfect setting for Stanley's unnerving ritual.
28) Jack infiltrated the mill, its vast echoey an ominous stage.
29) He arrived right as Stanley was preparing to commence the hideous ritual.
30) The sight of the children, bound and gagged, sent a wave of righteous fury through him, elevating the stakes at hand.
31) The confrontation that followed was a high-stakes face-off between Jack and Stanley.
32) In the ensuing struggle, Stanley managed to precariously initiate the ritual.
33) Racing against time, Jack successfully sabotaged the devilish alter, neutralizing the imminent catastrophe Stanley had planned.
34) Despite the injuries that racked his body, Jack pulled through the ordeal.
35) His relentless grit had finally neutralized the faceless horror to Middleton's serenity.
36) Recovering in the veteran hospital of Middleton, Jack basked in the newfound respect from his colleagues, who now saw him as the town's unsung hero.
37) At the heart of the rejoicing, Jack reminded his fellow officers of the symbolic importance of their badges - an enduring commitment to shield their community from threats obscure and conspicuous.
38) Jack, in his ever-modest demeanor, dismissed any heroic tag, highlighting the shared responsibility among all law enforcers to remain vigilant, always ready to face incognito threats lurking in their idyllic neighborhoods.
39) Jack played a vital role in reuniting the rescued children with their euphoric families.
40) His relentless pursuit of justice had once more reinstated a sense of safety in the heart of Middleton, reaffirming the town's faith in the law.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist in the story is Officer Jack Reynolds. Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. **Initial Encounter with Stanley**: Jack investigates a suspicious vehicle and meets Stanley (sentences 3-6).
2. **Dismissal by Superiors**: Jack's concerns about Stanley are dismissed by his superiors (sentences 9-10).
3. **Confrontation in the Alleyway**: Jack is attacked by Stanley and suffers physical injuries (sentences 14-15).
4. **Discovery of the Underground Bunker**: Jack uncovers evidence of Stanley's dark practices and connection to the town's disturbances (sentences 19-21).
5. **Final Confrontation and Resolution**: Jack sabotages Stanley's ritual and saves the children, earning respect and recognition from his colleagues (sentences 31-40).

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes at Each Event

1. **Initial Encounter with Stanley**: Jack is vigilant and instinctively alert, but his state is relatively neutral. He is simply doing his job.
2. **Dismissal by Superiors**: Jack's concerns are dismissed, leaving him feeling frustrated and unsupported. His state worsens relative to the previous event.
3. **Confrontation in the Alleyway**: Jack suffers physical injuries and is shaken, but his determination to uncover the truth strengthens. His physical state worsens, but his resolve improves.
4. **Discovery of the Underground Bunker**: Jack is horrified by what he discovers, but his suspicions are confirmed, and he feels vindicated. His state improves relative to the previous event, as he is now more confident in his pursuit of justice.
5. **Final Confrontation and Resolution**: Jack successfully thwarts Stanley's plan, earns recognition from his colleagues, and feels a sense of pride and fulfillment. His state improves significantly relative to the previous events.

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as **Man in a Hole**. The protagonist, Jack, starts in a relatively neutral state, falls into a dilemma (dismissal by superiors and physical injuries), and then finds a way out (discovery of the underground bunker and final confrontation). His state improves from the first turning point (dismissal by superiors) to the last turning point (final confrontation and resolution).

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

**Man in a Hole**

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In Swinton, Louisiana, police officer Kevin Ganning pulls over a green van for not having a license plate.
2) Ganning demands the driver to leave their vehicle.
3) When Ganning notices a bloody rag, he aggressively demands the driver to exit the vehicle.
4) When Ganning points his gun at the driver, an unknown entity pulls him away.
5) 12 hours earlier, Officer Renee Lomito-Smith is being cleared to return to active duty after an altercation with a civilian and is paired with rookie Danny Holledge.
6) They get a call from dispatch where officer Ganning is "failing to respond."
7) Officers Lomito-Smith and Holledge go to investigate Ganning's last known location.
8) Lomito-Smith finds the dash-cam footage in the police car, where she witnesses Ganning's beating from an unknown entity.
9) They soon find Ganning's lifeless body hanging and call it in.
10) Sergeant Kesper tells them the footage has been destroyed, long before Lomito-Smith and Holledge had arrived.
11) Lomito-Smith soon gets a lead, when she recognizes the logo of a hospital from the driver's pants.
12) She is then able to get the identity and home address of the driver; Taneesha Branz.
13) She and Holledge arrive at Taneesha's home and discover it has been abandoned.
14) While checking the home, they find a photo of Taneesha and her son.
15) Holledge leaves quickly when he becomes too scared because of roaches.
16) Officer Lomito-Smith is unable to find anything and leaves.
17) As she goes to exit, she finds that it is locked and as she tries to get out, she realizes the entity is watching her.
18) As if it is intending to kill her, Renee breaks the window on the door.
19) Lomito-Smith investigates Taneesha; she discovers her son Demarco was killed in a gang shoot out.
20) Taneesha shops in a grocery’s store late at night where she is immediately harassed by two men in-store.
21) Officers Roberts and Birke spot the green van, calling for backup.
22) Lomito-Smith and Holledge answer the call for help and change their route to provide assistance to Roberts and Birke.
23) Birke and Roberts enter the store and question the two men aggressively, despite neither man showing any hostility towards the officers.
24) One of the men shoots and kills Birke as he takes Taneesha hostage.
25) As he threatens to kill Taneesha, the entity suddenly lifts him into the air, freeing Taneesha.
26) He fires his gun attempting to escape; accidentally killing the store clerk as well as his partner.
27) Taneesha slips out through the back exit during the commotion.
28) Roberts investigates the shooter's last location, only for his bloodied body to fall onto the floor from above.
29) He attempts to warn Roberts the entity is behind him (as he cannot speak).
30) The entity attempts to suffocate Roberts with a bag, and when the attempt fails, it lifts him into the air and kills him off-screen.
31) The bloodied man dies from his injuries.
32) Officers Lomito-Smith and Holledge arrive at the store, and find everyone dead.
33) Lomito-Smith investigates in the rear parts of the store, finding no one.
34) She discovers the security camera footage is unusable.
35) When she goes back into the store, she finds the phone belonging to one of the men and steals it hoping to find a lead.
36) After returning to the station, she visits the medical examiner to get details about the victims.
37) The medical examiner explains how the body is damaged in the most unusual way but points out victims had their teeth knocked out.
38) Lomito-Smith pleads with the medical examiner to give her five minutes alone with the bodies.
39) He agrees, but tells her she cannot steal anything or disrupt the bodies.
40) She pulls out the phone that she found at the store, unlocking it with the thumbprint of one of the two men.
41) Later that evening, she reviews the video from the phone, noticing the entity behind Taneesha and the man holding her hostage.
42) Lomito-Smith gets a lead on the origin of the green van, where it was reported stolen.
43) She heads to an unnamed church and questions the Pastor, deducing the van was never stolen.
44) The Pastor explains Taneesha's son, Demarco, was deaf and avid volunteer to many organizations.
45) When Lomito-Smith asks where Taneesha could be, the Pastor gives a possible location.
46) She only finds articles of Demarco's death alongside photos of Officers Ganning, Roberts, Holledge, and Penda.
47) Officer Lomito-Smith sees a camera watching her.
48) She tries to call Sergeant Kesper, but he does not pick up.
49) She then calls Holledge and says she needs to talk to him face-to-face.
50) He agrees that she can come over in one hour.
51) Renee goes to Danny's house and discovers he has committed suicide.
52) The grief-stricken Renee finds a note left on the sink, "I'm sorry, Danny", along with a flash drive.
53) Renee inserts the flash drive into her computer.
54) It reveals Holledge's body cam footage of himself and officers Ganning, Roberts, and Penda during a police stop.
55) It shows where they are yelling at a young man to stop walking under the assumption he is a suspect.
56) Penda shoots him when the young man refuses to stop.
57) Roberts hands the cell phone to Penda and goes the young man's backpack.
58) Penda realizes the young man was Demarco, Taneesha's deaf son.
59) Officer Holledge points out his teeth came out, but Penda tells Holledge how bad this situation is.
60) Penda suffocates Demarco.
61) Lomito-Smith calls Sergeant Kesper.
62) She meets him at a warehouse and tells him what the four officers did to Demarco.
63) Kesper pulls his gun on Renee and tells her the incident best left covered and it will do more harm than good.
64) As she walks inside the building at gun point, Officer Penda emerges from his car and follows behind them.
65) Penda demands Renee to hand over the footage.
66) When she refuses, Penda shoots into her Kevlar vest.
67) Taneesha appears and speaks to Penda, "YOU KILLED MY SON, DEMARCO.
68) YOU REMEMBER HIM?
69) BECAUSE HE REMEMBERS YOU."
70) The entity is revealed as Demarco's vengeful spirit, who beats up Sergeant Kesper and knocks his teeth out.
71) Renee and Taneesha escape to another part of the warehouse with Penda in pursuit.
72) Demarco's spirit finally takes his revenge; removing Penda's innards from his body and impaling him onto a large pipe.
73) As Renee readies herself to confront Demarco, Taneesha reveals he will not harm her.
74) Emergency services arrive to the scene.
75) Renee and Taneesha see both of their sons together, signifying they have now found peace and can move on.
76) Kesper, who survived Demarco's attack, is sent to prison.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Officer Renee Lomito-Smith.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Event 1: Officer Lomito-Smith is cleared to return to active duty after an altercation with a civilian and is paired with rookie Danny Holledge (Sentence 5).
2. Event 2: Lomito-Smith discovers the dash-cam footage in the police car, where she witnesses Ganning's beating from an unknown entity (Sentence 8).
3. Event 3: Lomito-Smith finds Danny's body after he commits suicide and discovers the truth about the police officers' involvement in Demarco's death (Sentences 51-60).
4. Event 4: Sergeant Kesper pulls his gun on Renee and tells her the incident is best left covered, leading to a confrontation with Officer Penda (Sentences 62-66).
5. Event 5: Demarco's spirit takes revenge on Penda, and Renee and Taneesha escape, finding peace and closure (Sentences 70-75).

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event

1. Event 1: Officer Lomito-Smith is in a relatively stable state, having just returned to active duty. Her condition is neutral (5/10).
2. Event 2: Lomito-Smith is in a state of concern and investigation, trying to understand the mysterious entity and Ganning's death. Her condition has decreased slightly (4/10).
3. Event 3: Lomito-Smith is in a state of shock, grief, and anger after discovering the truth about the police officers' involvement in Demarco's death. Her condition has decreased significantly (1/10).
4. Event 4: Lomito-Smith is in a state of danger and confrontation, facing off against Sergeant Kesper and Officer Penda. Her condition remains low (2/10).
5. Event 5: Lomito-Smith is in a state of relief, peace, and closure, having escaped the confrontation and found justice for Demarco's death. Her condition has increased significantly (8/10).

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I classify the story arc type as "Double Man in a Hole." The protagonist's condition decreases twice (Events 2 and 3) and then increases twice (Events 4 and 5), forming two cycles of dilemma and recovery.

The story arc type is characterized by two distinct dips in the protagonist's condition, followed by a recovery and ultimate improvement. This matches the pattern of the "Double Man in a Hole" story arc.

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

Double Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The film sweeps into motion with Arthur, a brilliant student, addressing a packed auditorium in the National University Debate Championships.
2) He proffers an ironclad argument about nuclear disarmament that leaves his competitors stunned and his professors nodding in approval.
3) As the ornate lecture hall reverberates with applause and praise for Arthur's victory, the young prodigy is plagued by an unsettling emptiness.
4) Recognition and accolades fail to fulfill him, sparking introspective ponderings on his purpose.
5) Back in the understated luxury of his Ivy League dorm room within Columbia University, Arthur stumbles upon an old, discolored letter from his late father, a renowned archaeologist.
6) He reads about a distant indigenous village off the beaten path in Montana, intriguingly named Bison Hide Haven.
7) Captivated by the allure of the unfamiliar, Arthur spends the night thoroughly researching the mysterious indigenous settlement.
8) He learns about the peculiar tradition of bison hide trade that is central to the village's vibrant existence.
9) Astounding his esteemed professors and baffled classmates, Arthur opts to trade his poised academic life within the ivy-covered facades of Columbia for a chance to experience the gritty authenticity of Montana's wilderness.
10) Embarking on a journey that sends his heart into a tizzy of fear and exhilaration, Arthur boards a train heading west, carrying a bag of city essentials and a desire to unearth a life beyond the skyscrapers.
11) Reaching Bison Hide Haven, he is entranced by the hustle and heartfelt simplicity of the villagers.
12) The rugged reality of life marked by crafting hides and swapping goods is a stark contrast to his prior existence lost among towering steel buildings and bustling subways.
13) Strangers in this close-knit community observe his arrival with caution, their curiosity piqued by his alien city-life manners, visible in the creases of his impeccable Columbia University jacket.
14) Met with the initial reluctance of the villagers, Arthur pushes onwards earnestly, slowly gaining understanding and skill in the intricate process of bison hide processing, which acts as the axis around which the community revolves.
15) We meet Constance, the sharp-witted yet affectionate owner of the local watering hole - The Rusty Barrel Saloon, and Daren, a brooding, notorious figure who oversees the bison hide trade.
16) He soon finds mentorship in Jacob, a respected elder, famous for his bison-hunting prowess and trade acumen, providing Arthur with profound insights into the law of the wild and principles of trading.
17) Jacob instills in Arthur an understanding of the delicate equilibrium of nature, particularly concerning the bison population, a crucial link in maintaining the health of the local ecosystem and the economic stability of Bison Hide Haven.
18) Concurrently, Arthur's admiration for Constance blooms, inspired by how she expertly juggles the boisterous saloon patrons and the steadfast precision with which she handles the saloon's finances.
19) Drowned in his warm liquor and unexpressed feelings for Constance, Daren grows irritated by Arthur's frequent presence at the saloon and his evident camaraderie with the audacious saloon owner.
20) Daren's bristling antagonism towards Arthur escalates as he notices the burgeoning rapport between the city-bred newcomer and Constance, initiating a bitter rivalry between the polished outsider and the gruff local.
21) Faced with Daren's increasing hostility, Arthur finds himself pitted against the coldly focused, threatening gaze of the local gunslinger more frequently than he had expected.
22) Galvanized by the wisdom imbued in his father's letters and his newfound convictions, Arthur decides to stand up to Daren, teeing up a confrontation with the village outlaw.
23) True to his outlaw persona, Daren, decked in his intimidating black duster coat and customary wild west hat, dares Arthur to a classic sunset duel, quintessential in its wild-west machismo.
24) Despite his unfamiliarity with guns and the ways of the west, a determined Arthur accepts the challenge, eager to liberate the villagers from Daren's firm grip, protect his burgeoning love, Constance, and the village's integral bison population.
25) News of the impending showdown scurrying around the modest earthen houses, the normally serene atmosphere of Bison Hide Haven is charged with uncertain anticipation, bringing daily chores to a halt.
26) Ignoring the fear gripping him as he stares down the barrel of Daren's prized LeMat Revolver, Arthur garners courage from his father's enduring spirit resonating within him.
27) In an unforeseen turn of events that leaves bystanders astonished, Arthur manages to outdraw the feared outlaw in the sunset showdown.
28) This act of unexpected courage catapults Arthur into a new light among the villagers, prompting their acceptance of him as their own.
29) His endeavor strikes a chord, stirring respect for the city-boy who staked everything for their Haven's welfare.
30) Embracing his victory and the deep-seated relief that accompanies it, Arthur makes a life-altering decision to make Bison Hide Haven his home, departing from his high-paced New York City life for good.
31) Under Arthur's insightful guidance, the bison hide trade gradually evolves into a sustainable enterprise, striking a balance between the villagers' economic needs and the preservation of the local wildlife ecosystem.
32) As the film moves towards its conclusion, we see Arthur and Constance nestled comfortably in the familiar surroundings of Rusty Barrel Saloon, kindling hopes of a blooming romance in coming times.
33) The final frame fades out leaving the audience on an expectant note, eagerly awaiting Arthur’s ensuing adventures in the Heartland and the promising love story with Constance in potential sequels.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Arthur.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Arthur wins the National University Debate Championships but feels unfulfilled (sentences 1-3).
2. Arthur discovers his late father's letter and decides to leave his academic life for Montana's wilderness (sentences 5-10).
3. Arthur faces initial reluctance from the villagers in Bison Hide Haven but eventually gains their respect (sentences 11-14, 17).
4. Arthur's rivalry with Daren escalates into a sunset duel (sentences 20-24).
5. Arthur wins the duel, earns the villagers' acceptance, and decides to stay in Bison Hide Haven (sentences 27-30).

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes at Each Event

1. Arthur wins the National University Debate Championships but feels unfulfilled:
	* State: High social status, but emotionally unfulfilled.
	* Change: This event marks the beginning of Arthur's journey, and his emotional state is already in a state of dissatisfaction.
2. Arthur discovers his late father's letter and decides to leave his academic life:
	* State: Curious, seeking a new path, and uncertain.
	* Change: Arthur's state has shifted from emotional dissatisfaction to a sense of curiosity and uncertainty, as he leaves behind his familiar life.
3. Arthur faces initial reluctance from the villagers but eventually gains their respect:
	* State: Struggling to adapt, but determined.
	* Change: Arthur's state has changed from uncertainty to determination, as he works to gain the villagers' respect.
4. Arthur's rivalry with Daren escalates into a sunset duel:
	* State: Threatened, but resolute.
	* Change: Arthur's state has shifted from determination to a sense of threat, as he faces the hostility of Daren.
5. Arthur wins the duel, earns the villagers' acceptance, and decides to stay:
	* State: Triumphant, accepted, and at peace.
	* Change: Arthur's state has changed from being threatened to being triumphant, as he earns the villagers' acceptance and finds a new sense of purpose.

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole." Here's my reasoning:

* Arthur starts in a high social status but feels emotionally unfulfilled (Event 1).
* He then leaves his familiar life and faces uncertainty and challenges in the wilderness (Event 2).
* He struggles to adapt but eventually gains the villagers' respect (Event 3).
* He faces a significant threat from Daren but emerges triumphant (Event 4).
* Ultimately, he finds acceptance and a new sense of purpose in Bison Hide Haven (Event 5).

This narrative arc follows the "Man in a Hole" pattern, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma (leaving his academic life) and finds a way out (gaining the villagers' respect and winning the duel), ending in a better state than at the beginning.

### TASK 4: Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 1874, Will Andrews, the naive son of a pastor, has dropped out of Harvard and travels to Butcher's Crossing, a tiny frontier town in Kansas built on the buffalo hide trade.
2) He wishes to see as much of the country as he can and experience the Wild West.
3) Sold on the romanticism of going on a buffalo hunt, Will seeks out McDonald, a former acquaintance of his father's, who currently runs the waning buffalo trade for the town.
4) When McDonald refuses to oblige the young man, Will falls in with Miller, an intense and experienced buffalo hunter who spins him a tale of a remote Colorado pass where one of the few remaining massive herds can be found.
5) Though warned about Miller and the folly of this enterprise, Will puts up all of his money to fund the expedition.
6) With Will's money, they purchase supplies and hire Charlie Hoge, a drunk, one armed, bible-thumper, to be wagon driver and camp cook, and Fred Schneider, a crude, but pragmatic, 'skinner' who insists on being paid a salary due to his doubts about Miller's stories.
7) The journey to the pass is difficult for Will, who is thrilled and enchanted with the scenery, but unused to rigorous hardships.
8) The team encounters many difficulties which make them doubt the veracity of Miller's claim and ability to lead them, and Will's sanity begins to falter, but eventually they reach the mountain pass to discover an untouched herd with thousands upon thousands of buffalo.
9) Will is ecstatic and awed, believing the beautiful nature surrounding them is "God", elated at being able to experience something so beautiful.
10) Miller begins his hunt.
11) What starts as a thrilling adventure soon becomes an obsessive, methodical onslaught of endless slaughter.
12) Miller revels in dropping hundreds of buffalo a day, leaving Will and Schneider scrambling to skin the carcasses, with Miller refusing to slow down his kills.
13) The ceaseless rounds of blood and butchery wear on Will and his mental and physical health, as he begins to feel their presence is corrupting the sacred space of the pass.
14) He becomes numb to the gore as time passes and the valley becomes filled with skinned corpses.
15) After three weeks of constant butchery, Schneider points out that they have overstayed their intended time and already have more hides than they can carry.
16) He proposes they stop and return before the weather turns and they become trapped.
17) Miller refuses.
18) He is obsessed and won't stop until every buffalo in the herd is dead.
19) Will sides with Miller and the team stays to continue the slaughter despite Schneider's protests at the pointless waste of killing more than they can carry.
20) Predictably, the team becomes trapped by a blizzard.
21) They are now forced to live out the winter in the mountains.
22) They are low on food, because they have killed all but a handful of the buffalo and left the previous carcasses to rot.
23) Schneider is frustrated at becoming trapped because they wouldn't listen, and lashes out at Hoge, who has descended into paranoid religious mutterings.
24) In revenge, Hoge poisons Schneider's food.
25) Will's sanity slips further, and Miller obsesses over the triumph of returning to town with the largest haul ever seen once he's killed every single buffalo.
26) The team settles in to endure a long, boring slog of survival as they wait the winter out.
27) When spring comes, Hoge is killed after the poisoning is discovered, and the team is antsy to return.
28) Unable to haul all of the 4,600 hides they have collected, they pile 1,600 in their wagon, and leave the remaining 3,000 with the intent to return for them.
29) An exultant Miller is impatient to return to the town, triumphant with his haul, but their damaged wagon falls off a cliff, taking Scheider and the 1,600 hides with it, as Miller and Will numbly stare on.
30) Will and Miller rush to town, hoping to get another wagon in order to return for the 3,000 remaining hides.
31) But Butcher's Crossing is much changed.
32) Largely abandoned and derelict, the pair are horrified to learn that the bottom has fallen out of the buffalo hide market while they were trapped for the winter.
33) Had they returned the previous fall, as intended, instead of been greedy and stayed until every buffalo was killed, they could have sold their hides and become immensely wealthy.
34) Now, with no buyers, the hides are completely worthless, and the town collapsed once its main source of commerce dried up.
35) Robbed of his victory, Miller sets the old buffalo exchange building on fire.
36) A much-changed Will says he has "seen what [he] needed to see" on the buffalo hunt when asked if the experience was worth it, and rides into the wilderness, alone.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
**Task 1: Identify the protagonist and 5 major events in the story**

The protagonist of the story is Will Andrews. Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Will drops out of Harvard and travels to Butcher's Crossing, seeking adventure and experience in the Wild West. (Sentence 1)
2. Will and Miller's team reaches the remote Colorado pass and discovers an untouched herd of thousands of buffalo, fulfilling Will's desire for a thrilling experience. (Sentence 8)
3. The team becomes trapped in the mountains due to a blizzard, and Will's mental and physical health begins to deteriorate. (Sentence 20)
4. The team returns to Butcher's Crossing after a long and difficult winter, only to find that the buffalo hide market has collapsed, rendering their haul worthless. (Sentence 32)
5. Will, changed by his experiences, rides off into the wilderness alone, reflecting on the value of his journey. (Sentence 36)

**Task 2: Describe the protagonist's state and changes at each event**

1. At the beginning of the story, Will is naive and idealistic, seeking adventure and experience in the Wild West. His state is one of optimism and anticipation.
2. Upon discovering the untouched buffalo herd, Will is ecstatic and awed, feeling that he has experienced something truly beautiful and meaningful. His state has improved, as he has achieved his goal of experiencing the Wild West.
3. When the team becomes trapped in the mountains, Will's mental and physical health begins to deteriorate. He becomes numb to the gore and slaughter, and his state worsens, as he is forced to confront the harsh realities of his adventure.
4. Upon returning to Butcher's Crossing and finding that the buffalo hide market has collapsed, Will is faced with the reality of his own foolishness and the pointlessness of the slaughter. His state worsens further, as he is forced to confront the consequences of his actions.
5. In the end, Will is changed by his experiences, and his state is one of reflection and introspection. He has learned a valuable lesson about the nature of reality and the importance of considering the consequences of one's actions.

**Task 3: Classify the story arc type and explain reasoning**

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as Icarus. The Icarus story arc is characterized by a rise to success followed by a drastic downfall. In this story, Will's state improves initially, as he achieves his goal of experiencing the Wild West and discovers the untouched buffalo herd. However, his state worsens as he becomes trapped in the mountains and is forced to confront the harsh realities of his adventure. Finally, his state worsens further when he returns to Butcher's Crossing and finds that the buffalo hide market has collapsed, rendering his haul worthless. This pattern of rise and fall is consistent with the Icarus story arc type.

**Task 4: State the determined story arc type**

Icarus

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The yellow U-Haul moving truck groans under the strain of the load and emits a puff of exhaust before moving away from the curbside.
2) Liam, an enigmatic teenager diagnosed with autism, gazes forlornly at the home they're leaving behind.
3) As the house recedes, he retreats into his iPhone, seeking distraction and comfort in the vibrant glow of his favorite puzzle-solving app.
4) Inside the van, Mark and Susan, his parents, covertly observe their son's quiet struggle to cope with the sudden immersion into an unfamiliar environment.
5) They exchange a glance, a silent communication of their shared concern for their son who has always been anxious about changes.
6) The next day, Mark dons his crisp suit and heads out for his first day at HexTech Chemical Plant.
7) The promotion, a significant turning point in his career, cast rigid lines of anxiety and strain in a family that thrived on casual, peaceful dynamics.
8) Liam's existing anxieties seemed to climax, in sync with his father's mounting professional stress.
9) One day, while seated on the peeling paint of a park bench in Maplewood's main park, Liam's finger pauses over the screen of his iPhone.
10) Suddenly, a cryptic message pops up on his gaming app, filled with symbols that even his proficient mind found challenging to decode.
11) Despite his parents' assessment, the mysterious message troubled Liam.
12) It reappeared on his phone, this time accompanied by veiled threats hinting peril towards his family.
13) Each recurrence, more menacing than the past, disrupts Liam’s prior tranquillity.
14) Resolute yet scared, his confidante, the iPhone, mirrored his fear.
15) The change in their son worried Mark and Susan.
16) They approached Dr. Amanda Greenfield, a respected authority in the field of autism and psychology, entrusting her with their son’s peculiar actions.
17) Although they respected Dr. Greenfield's expertise, Mark and Susan couldn’t fully accept the explanation provided by her.
18) The inexplicable incidents that progressively occurred around their new house escalated their suspicion.
19) Using his extraordinary understanding of patterns and sequences, Liam embarked on a self-initiated investigation.
20) A series of suspicious activities around the serene town of Maplewood emerged from his in-depth analysis.
21) His startling findings insinuated an unfavorable operation taking place.
22) Liam’s relentless pursuit for truth eventually caught the attention of the privacy-craving criminals who now perceived him as a threat.
23) Simultaneously, the unsettling occurrences in their newly-acquired house amplified.
24) Fastidious pattern analysis led Liam to finally pinpoint the imminent threat specified in the menacing messages.
25) With conclusive evidence and alarming predictions, he convinced Mark and Susan of the impending disaster.
26) They approached both the Maplewood Local Police Center and Maplewood Middle School Guidance, providing pieces of photographic evidence and unraveling the situation.
27) Doing so led to the prevention of a potentially disastrous chemical leak.
28) The criminals, who cunningly concealed their operations behind a software company’s facade, were apprehended.
29) Every coded threat was traced back to Liam's phone, which turned out to be the crucial link that exposed their nefarious plans.
30) The people of Maplewood hailed Liam, an ordinary autistic teenager with an extraordinary mind, as a local hero.
31) His unique capability led to the safeguarding of the town.
32) The family found their peace in their new home, embracing Liam's extraordinary abilities that had earlier gone unnoticed.
33) Liam's iPhone transformed from a mere communication device into a beacon of hope for the small town.
34) The series of events brought the family closer together.
35) They learned to understand and appreciate Liam's unique perspective on the world and in turn, changed their perspective of life.
36) His unmatched ability to perceive patterns led them through an extraordinary adventure, ultimately strengthening their bond as a family.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
**Task 1: Identify the protagonist and major events**

The protagonist of the story is Liam, an enigmatic teenager diagnosed with autism.

Five major events in the story are:

1. The family moves away from their home, causing Liam distress (sentences 1-5).
2. Liam receives a cryptic message on his iPhone, leading to increased anxiety (sentences 9-13).
3. Liam discovers a pattern of suspicious activities in Maplewood and decides to investigate (sentences 19-21).
4. Liam's findings lead to the prevention of a potentially disastrous chemical leak, and the criminals are apprehended (sentences 24-28).
5. Liam is hailed as a local hero, and his family comes to appreciate his unique abilities (sentences 30-36).

**Task 2: Describe the protagonist's state at each event**

1. At the first event, Liam is in a state of distress and anxiety due to the sudden change in his environment. His condition is low.
2. At the second event, Liam's anxiety increases due to the cryptic message, making his condition even lower than before.
3. At the third event, Liam becomes resolute and determined to investigate the suspicious activities, indicating a slight improvement in his condition.
4. At the fourth event, Liam's findings lead to a successful outcome, and his condition improves significantly as he gains confidence and recognition.
5. At the fifth event, Liam is hailed as a hero, and his family comes to appreciate his unique abilities, leading to a further improvement in his condition.

**Task 3: Classify the story arc type**

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, the story arc type can be classified as "Man in a Hole." Liam starts in a low state due to the move, falls even lower due to the cryptic message, but then begins to recover as he investigates the suspicious activities. His condition continues to improve as he achieves success and recognition, ultimately ending in a much better state than at the beginning.

This classification is consistent with the "Man in a Hole" story arc, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma (the move and the cryptic message) but finds a way out (through his investigation and determination) and ends better than at the beginning.

**Task 4: State the determined story arc type**

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Oliver is a young non-verbal autistic boy who uses a smartphone to communicate with people.
2) He attends school and is mostly taken care of by his mother, Sarah; his father Marty spends most of his time at work trying to make ends meet.
3) Sarah and Marty's marriage has become difficult to the extent that Marty moves out.
4) One night Oliver sees an app on his smartphone, "Misunderstood Monsters", narrating the story of a monster named Larry who "just wants a friend".
5) After he reads the story, lights go out by themselves.
6) He plays with an app on his tablet that identifies faces, and it identifies a face in the empty space next to him.
7) At school, Oliver is bullied by his classmates due to his condition.
8) They lure him into a field and take his phone, throwing it out into the field.
9) One night, Sarah organizes a sleepover so Oliver can become more social.
10) The three boys who bullied him come over.
11) Oliver hides the tablet as he is terrified of it.
12) One of the boys retrieves the tablet and reads the story.
13) The lights go out and Larry appears, but he can only be seen through the tablet's camera.
14) Larry attacks Byron, one of the boys, and the terrified boys all blame Oliver for the incident.
15) In the following days, Sarah begins to see the same strange things Oliver did.
16) Through Oliver's tablet, Larry says he wants to take Oliver back to his home world.
17) That night, Marty takes Oliver to his night-shift parking lot attendant job.
18) Larry, revealing as a skeletal creature similar to a ghoul, begins to stalk them.
19) When Marty witnesses Larry picking Oliver off from the ground, he finally believes Sarah and Oliver.
20) They break the tablet and assume everything is over.
21) Byron is traumatized from the incident at Oliver's house but comes clean on what really happened, absolving Oliver of blame.
22) It is revealed that Byron and Oliver were once good friends but their friendship ended badly because Oliver accidentally hurt Byron which also caused their moms to break up their friendship.
23) They both reconcile, with Oliver and Byron becoming friends again.
24) One night at work, Marty is attacked by Larry, who can travel through electricity and usually communicates with people through screens.
25) Marty is hurt but alive.
26) Larry proceeds to attack Oliver at his house, intending to take the boy.
27) Sarah trashes all electrical devices in the house, but the TV finishes playing Larry's story before she can shut it off.
28) Larry takes physical form, being able to move in real life without the use of a screen, and begins to stalk them throughout the house.
29) Oliver takes Sarah to the field where there is no electricity for Larry to follow them with, but Larry uses Oliver's phone that the boys threw earlier to trap them there.
30) Oliver must take Larry's hand to enter Larry's world, but at the last second, Sarah takes Larry's hand instead, offering to go with him and become his friend instead of Oliver.
31) In their final moments, Oliver looks Sarah in the eye for the first time, something Sarah has struggled with ever since Oliver was diagnosed.
32) Larry takes Sarah and they both vanish, leaving Oliver alone.
33) In the aftermath, Oliver lives with Marty, and they intend to deal with their loss.
34) Marty gets more involved with Oliver's therapy.
35) One night, the lights go out again and strange noises are heard downstairs.
36) Marty grabs his phone and sees Oliver and Sarah (who has been taken by Larry and seemingly lives in his world) playing happily.
37) Sarah tells her son "I'll protect you", as Marty smiles.
38) Larry's fate is left unknown.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist in the story is Oliver, a young non-verbal autistic boy.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. **Event 1: Oliver's family situation deteriorates** (Sentences 1-3)
Oliver's family situation becomes difficult, with his parents' marriage strained, and his father eventually moving out.

2. **Event 2: Oliver discovers the "Misunderstood Monsters" app and is bullied** (Sentences 4-9)
Oliver finds the "Misunderstood Monsters" app, which leads to a series of supernatural events. He is also bullied by his classmates, who take his phone and throw it into a field.

3. **Event 3: Larry takes physical form and stalks Oliver's family** (Sentences 24-28)
Larry, the monster from the app, takes physical form and begins to stalk Oliver's family, intending to take Oliver.

4. **Event 4: Sarah sacrifices herself to save Oliver** (Sentences 30-32)
Sarah offers to go with Larry instead of Oliver, saving her son but leaving him alone.

5. **Event 5: Oliver and Marty cope with their loss, but find hope** (Sentences 33-37)
Oliver and his father, Marty, deal with the loss of Sarah, but eventually find hope when they see Sarah and Oliver playing happily together in Larry's world through Marty's phone.

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes

Here's how Oliver's state changes throughout the story:

* **Event 1:** Oliver's state is vulnerable and uncertain due to his family situation.
* **Event 2:** Oliver's state worsens as he faces bullying and supernatural events that he doesn't understand.
* **Event 3:** Oliver's state becomes more desperate and fearful as Larry takes physical form and stalks his family.
* **Event 4:** Oliver's state is one of shock and grief as he loses his mother, but also relief that he is safe.
* **Event 5:** Oliver's state begins to heal as he and his father cope with their loss, and they find hope that Sarah is still with them in some way.

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on Oliver's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as **Man in a Hole**. Here's why:

* Oliver starts in a difficult situation (Event 1) and faces a series of challenges that worsen his state (Events 2-3).
* He hits rock bottom when he loses his mother (Event 4), but ultimately finds a way out of his difficulties and begins to heal (Event 5).
* The story ends on a hopeful note, with Oliver and his father finding a way to cope with their loss and even finding a sense of peace and connection with Sarah.

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The narrative commences in the transformative year of 2178, with Earth basking in a golden era of technology and bioengineering.
2) Amidst the hustle and bustle of this technological revolution, the crowded laboratory of Morgan Industries emerges as the nucleus of innovation.
3) Here, the indomitable force of nature, Dr. Elaine Morgan, an expert in bioengineering, is ceaselessly pushing the boundaries of the possible.
4) Dr. Morgan introduces her most revolutionary creation yet - the HeartGuard.
5) A Cardiac Regulation Device with a twist, this marvel of bioengineering has the potential to discern heart diseases within minutes and rectify them instantaneously.
6) However, as Elaine's professional life thrives, her personal life stands in stark contrast as an unrelenting tumult.
7) Elaine is often found arriving home in the late hours, her adolescent daughter, Sarah, asleep on the living room couch, her unfinished homework strewn across the coffee table, symbolic of a missed dinnertime spent together.
8) The story takes a poignant turn when a flashback uncovers Elaine’s motivation - an early demise of her mother due to an incurable congenital heart condition.
9) Despite her success, Elaine’s preoccupation with her work plants seeds of discord with her daughter.
10) Her revolutionary invention sparks heated debates worldwide, with critics questioning if the boundaries of bioengineering ethics have been overstepped.
11) Amidst this concern, Morgan Industries faces allegations of potential privacy infringement via biomedical intervention.
12) The controversy takes a perilous twist when Elaine's device is sabotaged during a live demonstration at a medical convention.
13) This disaster ignites pandemonium amongst the audience, shattering Elaine's reputation, and undermining the credibility of the HeartGuard.
14) Following this debacle, Elaine retreats to her lab, determined to rectify the vulnerabilities in her invention.
15) Consumed by her drive to mend the HeartGuard, Elaine becomes further engrossed in her work.
16) The estrangement between mother and daughter deepens, leading to bitter arguments and a silence that threatens their relationship.
17) In a twist of fate, Sarah unexpectedly succumbs to a heart attack at home.
18) With her daughter's life hanging in the balance, Elaine implants the still vulnerable HeartGuard device in Sarah.
19) Elaine manages to manually regulate Sarah's heartbeat using the device, saving her life.
20) Fired by this experience, Elaine dedicates herself unwaveringly to developing world-class encryption for HeartGuard to shield it from future hacking attempts.
21) Elaine reorganises her life, fostering healing and forgiveness by devoting more time to Sarah, nurturing a newfound emotional closeness.
22) With the HeartGuard secure, Elaine takes a step back from her hands-on role at Morgan Industries.
23) Years later, Sarah, now a mature, self-assured woman with a degree in bioengineering, takes the helm at Morgan Industries.
24) The narrative culminates by emphasizing a promising future for bioengineering, characterized by ethical considerations, responsibility and the ultimate goal: human well-being.
25) Now retired, Elaine spends her days contemplating the future she envisioned reflected in the horizon.
26) The movie concludes on a heartfelt note, with a warmly embracing Sarah and Elaine, symbolic of a passed torch and an unbreakable mother-daughter bond.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) At an unspecified future date, significant advances in biotechnology led to the invention of machines and (analogue) computers that can directly interface with and control bodily functions, which have become the norm.
2) Simultaneously, humankind itself has experienced several biological changes of indeterminate origin.
3) Most significant among these changes is the disappearance of physical pain and infectious disease for an overwhelming majority (allowing for surgery to be safely performed on conscious people in ordinary settings), but other humans experience more radical alterations to their physiology.
4) One of them, an eight-year-old boy named Brecken, displays the innate ability to consume and digest plastics as food.
5) Convinced that he is inhuman, Brecken's mother smothers him with a pillow, leaving his corpse to be found by her ex-husband Lang.
6) Saul Tenser and Caprice are a world-renowned performance artist couple.
7) They take advantage of Tenser's "accelerated evolution syndrome", a disorder that forces his body to constantly develop new organs, by surgically removing them before a live audience.
8) The syndrome leaves Tenser in constant pain and with severe respiratory and digestive discomfort; he is consequently reliant on several specialized biomechanical devices, including a bed, a machine through which Caprice performs surgery on him, and a chair that twitches and rotates as it assists him with eating.
9) Tenser and Caprice meet with bureaucrats in charge of the National Organ Registry, a governmental office designed to uphold the state's restrictions on human evolution by cataloging and storing newly evolved organs.
10) One of the bureaucrats, the nervy Timlin, becomes captivated by Tenser's artistic goals.
11) At a successful show of Tenser's, she tells him that "surgery is the new sex", a sentiment that Tenser and many other characters appear to embrace as repetitive cutting seems to be replacing traditional sex and masturbation as the preferred means of sexual gratification.
12) A governmental police unit seeks to use Tenser to infiltrate a group of radical evolutionists.
13) Without telling Caprice, Tenser meets a series of contacts through other biological performance art shows that lead him to the evolutionist cell.
14) One of them, former cosmetic surgeon Nasatir, creates a zippered cavern in Tenser's stomach, which Caprice uses to access Tenser's organs in an oral sex act where she fellates his zipper wound and presumably his internal organs while he moans in erotic pleasure.
15) Caprice continues to network with other performance artists, eventually choosing to receive decorative cosmetic surgery on her forehead.
16) Tenser meets with Timlin, who reveals to him the agenda of the evolutionists: they have chosen to modify their digestive system to make them able to eat plastics and other synthetic chemicals.
17) Their principal food is a purple processed "candy bar" of toxic waste, fatally poisonous to others.
18) Lang is the leader of the cell; his son Brecken had been born with the ability to eat plastic, proving the inaccuracy of the government's critical stance on human evolution.
19) Timlin tries to initiate sex with Tenser, but he says he is not good at "the old sex".
20) Tenser is eventually approached by Lang, who wants Tenser and Caprice to reveal the cell's anti-government agenda through a public autopsy of Brecken that will highlight his evolved digestive system.
21) After some deliberation, Tenser agrees.
22) With Timlin, Lang, and many others watching, Tenser performs the autopsy, but it is revealed that Brecken's natural organ system has been surgically replaced.
23) Lang flees the show in tears.
24) Outside, he is approached by two agents who supposedly work for the corporation that manufactures Tenser's biomedical machines.
25) Mimicking their earlier killing of Nasatir, they assassinate Lang by driving power drills into his head.
26) Tenser's connection within the police unit admits that Timlin replaced Brecken's organs to keep the deviation in human evolution secret from the public.
27) Saddened by Brecken and Lang's deaths, Tenser informs the police that he will no longer serve them, approvingly mentioning the cell's beliefs on evolution.
28) Tenser struggles to eat in his chair.
29) He asks Caprice to give him a bar of plastic.
30) As Caprice records him, he eats it, looks into Caprice's camera, and sheds a tear.
31) His mouth twitches into a smile as the chair finally quiets.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

output:
### TASK 1: Identify the protagonist and 5 major events

The protagonist of the story is Saul Tenser, a world-renowned performance artist with an "accelerated evolution syndrome" that forces his body to constantly develop new organs.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Tenser meets with bureaucrats in charge of the National Organ Registry and is approached by the governmental police unit to infiltrate a group of radical evolutionists (sentences 9-12).
2. Tenser meets Lang, the leader of the radical evolutionist cell, and agrees to perform a public autopsy of Brecken to reveal the cell's anti-government agenda (sentences 18-21).
3. The autopsy is performed, but it is revealed that Brecken's natural organ system has been surgically replaced, and Lang flees in tears (sentences 22-23).
4. Lang is assassinated by agents working for the corporation that manufactures Tenser's biomedical machines, and Tenser learns that Timlin replaced Brecken's organs to keep the deviation in human evolution secret (sentences 24-26).
5. Tenser decides to no longer serve the police, approves of the cell's beliefs on evolution, and eats a bar of plastic, symbolizing his acceptance of his condition and his newfound independence (sentences 27-31).

### TASK 2: Describe the protagonist's state at each event

1. At the meeting with bureaucrats, Tenser is in a state of dependence on the government and the police unit, using his condition to gain fame and attention. His state is relatively high, as he is a renowned performance artist.
2. When Tenser meets Lang, he is drawn to the radical evolutionist cell's ideology and begins to question his loyalty to the government. His state is one of curiosity and exploration.
3. After the autopsy, Tenser is shocked and saddened by the revelation that Brecken's organs were replaced, and he begins to feel a sense of betrayal. His state is lower than before, as he realizes the government's true intentions.
4. When Lang is assassinated, Tenser is further shocked and disillusioned with the government and the corporation that manufactures his machines. His state is even lower, as he feels trapped and controlled.
5. In the final scene, Tenser decides to break free from the government's control and accepts his condition, eating a bar of plastic and symbolizing his newfound independence. His state is higher than before, as he has found a sense of liberation and self-acceptance.

### TASK 3: Classify the story arc type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as Oedipus. Tenser starts in a relatively high state as a renowned performance artist, but then falls as he becomes embroiled in the conflict between the government and the radical evolutionist cell. He recovers somewhat as he finds a sense of purpose and belonging with the cell, but then faces another significant downfall as he realizes the government's true intentions and Lang is assassinated. Finally, he rises again as he breaks free from the government's control and accepts his condition.

### TASK 4: State the determined story arc type

Oedipus

26) From Nala's practical intelligence to Betty's infectious optimism, Jack's agile strength to Charlie’s innovative thinking, each one brings their unique strengths to the fore.
27) Together, they adapt and reconstruct their escape plan to tackle the advanced security, vigilant guards, and unexpected visitors at the mansion.
28) Against overwhelming odds, they achieve the impossible - the Duchess's Tear is stealthily procured!
29) Ecstatic and relieved, they also manage to expose Devaraueax's crimes, providing substantial evidence for the local sheriff.
30) Act 4 vows to a joyful union as Charlie, basking in the warmth of their victorious feat, stands by Rose's side in their reclaimed Serenity Manor.
31) The news of a lavish spring wedding soon fills the air.
32) Finally unmasked, Deveraux's reign of manipulation and deceit crashes and burns.
33) The town’s sheriff claps him in irons, bringing an end to his antics and delivering a resonating message of justice.
34) As Deveraux’s world crumbles, the love story of Betty and Sam flourishes into a passionate affair.
35) Their shared experiences deepen their bond and elevate their new-found love story from sweet to unforgettable.
36) The victory of retrieving the Duchess’s Tear feels minor in comparison to the personal triumphs.
37) The friends not only gain confidence in their abilities, but they also realize the invincibility of their camaraderie.
38) Moreover, the once quiet population of Magnolia Springs adorns a newfound respect, admiration and love for our four heroes.

22) He meets with Det.

24) Det.

29) They visit a strip club where they flash their earnings and are taken prisoner by Det.
30) Courtney and his men.

32) They return to the Ninth Ward and Det.

34) Symms and The Saint meet to discuss the situation.
35) Soon after, Bass presents himself to The Saint who shoots him in the head.
36) Some time later, the trio continue to find themselves in poverty.

38) The police swarm the building and all three men are seemingly killed in the ensuing firefight.
39) However, Blink is revealed to have survived and shown at the publishing of his graphic novel where Valencia congratulates him and he thanks her for giving him a second chance.
